page.title: List of Star Trek: The Original Series episodes

revisions.rev:
[[File:Star Trek TOS logo.svg|right|300px|link=:en:Star Trek: The Original Series]] {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Star Trek: The Original Series'' episodes}} Created by [[Gene Roddenberry]], the [[science fiction]] [[Television program|television series]] '''''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]''''' (which eventually acquired the [[retronym]] ''Star Trek: The Original Series'') starred [[William Shatner]] as [[James T. Kirk|Captain Kirk]], [[Leonard Nimoy]] as Mr. [[Spock]], and [[DeForest Kelley]] as [[Leonard McCoy|Dr. Leonard "Bones" McCoy]] aboard the fictional [[United Federation of Planets|Federation]] [[USS Enterprise (NCC-1701)|starship ''Enterprise'']]. The series originally aired from September 1966 through June 1969 on [[NBC]].<ref name="tos_nbc">{{cite book|last = Okuda|first = Michael and Denise| title = The Star Trek Encyclopedia (3rd ed.)| publisher = [[Pocket Books]]| location = New York| year = 1999| pages = 463| isbn = 0-671-53609-5 }}</ref>
This is the first television program in the [[Star Trek|''Star Trek'' franchise]], and comprises a total of 79 regular episodes over the show's three seasons, along with the show's original [[television pilot|pilot episode]], "[[The Cage (Star Trek: The Original Series)|The Cage]]". The episodes are listed in chronological order by original air date,<ref name="airdates">{{cite book|last = Trimble|first = Bjo| authorlink = Bjo Trimble| title = Star Trek Concordance| publisher = [[Ballantine Books]]| location = New York| year = 1976| pages = 37â89| isbn = 0-345-25137-7-695 }}</ref> which match the episode order in each season's original,<ref name="s1_dvd">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/releases/Star-Trek-Season-1/3771|title=Star Trek: Season 1 DVD Information|publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref><ref name="s2_dvd">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/releases/Star-Trek-Season-2/3820|title=Star Trek: Season 2 DVD Information|publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref><ref name="s3_dvd">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/releases/Star-Trek-Season-3/3821|title=Star Trek: Season 3 DVD Information|publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref> remastered,<ref name="s1_rem">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/releases/Star-Trek-Season-1-Remastered-HD-DVD/6973|title=Star Trek: Season 1 (Remastered) DVD Information|publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref><ref name="s2_rem">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/releases/Star-Trek-Season-2-Remastered/7736|title=Star Trek: Season 2 (Remastered) DVD Information|publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref><ref name="s3_rem">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/releases/Star-Trek-Season-3-Remastered/8147|title=Star Trek: Season 3 (Remastered) DVD Information|publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref> and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] DVD<ref name="bluray">{{cite web|url=http://trekmovie.com/2009/02/16/cbs-paramount-announce-first-star-trek-blu-ray-sets-tos-s1-all-tos-movies-coming-aprilmay/|title=CBS & Paramount Announce First Star Trek Blu-ray sets - TOS S1 & All TOS movies coming April/May|publisher=TrekMovie.com|date=2009-02-16|accessdate=2009-04-28}}</ref> box sets. The original, single-disc DVD releases placed the episodes by production order, with "The Cage" on the final disc.<ref name="indv_dvd">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/shows/Star-Trek/3971|title=Star Trek on DVD, Release Info, Reviews, News at TVShowsOnDVD.com|publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref> This list also includes the [[stardate]] on which the events of each episode took place within the fictional ''Star Trek'' universe.<ref name="stardates">{{cite book|last = Trimble|first = Bjo| authorlink = Bjo Trimble| title = Star Trek Concordance| publisher = [[Ballantine Books]]| location = New York| year = 1976| pages = 12â13| isbn = 0-345-25137-7-695 }}</ref>
After the show's [[Cancellation (television)|cancellation]], [[Paramount Television]] released ''Star Trek'' to television stations as a [[Broadcast syndication|syndication]] package,<ref name="synd_ads">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvobscurities.com/2008/12/star-trek-syndication-advertisements-circa-1969-1970/#cite1|title=Star Trek Syndication Advertisements, Circa 1969-1970|publisher=TelevisionObscurities.com|date=2008-12-15|accessdate=2009-05-02}}</ref> where the series' popularity grew to become a "major phenomenon within popular culture."<ref name="synd2">{{cite web|url=http://www.museum.tv/archives/etv/S/htmlS/startrek/startrek.htm|title=Star Trek (U.S. Science Fiction)|publisher=Museum.tv ( The Museum of Broadcast Communication)|accessdate=2009-05-02}}</ref> This popularity would eventually lead the ''Star Trek'' franchise to expand its catalog to include [[Star Trek#Television series|five more television series]] and [[Star Trek (film series)|eleven ''Trek'' motion pictures]].
In 2006, [[CBS Paramount Domestic Television]] (now [[CBS Television Distribution]]) announced that each ''Original Series'' episode would be re-syndicated in [[High-definition television|high definition]] after undergoing [[Star Trek: The Original Series#Remastered series|digital remastering]], including both new and enhanced [[visual effects]].<ref name="remastered_annoucement">{{cite web|url=http://trekmovie.com/2006/08/30/its-official-classic-trek-coming-to-hdtv-with-new-cgi-effectswe-called-it/|title=It's Official: Classic Trek Coming to HDTV With New CGI|publisher=TrekMovie.com|date=2006-08-30|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref> (To date, the remastered episodes have only been broadcast in [[Standard-definition television|standard definition]], though all three seasons are now available on the high-definition [[Blu-ray Disc]] format.)<ref name="TOS Format">{{cite web|url=http://trekmovie.com/tos-in-hd/|title=TOS Remastered: Format|publisher=TrekMovie.com|date=2006-08-30|accessdate=2009-04-30}}</ref><ref name="TOS S1 Blu-Ray">{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/movies.php?id=4189|title=Star Trek: The Original Series - Season 1 Blu-ray|publisher=blu-ray.com|date=2009-04-28|accessdate=2009-06-03}}</ref> The remastered episodes began with "[[Balance of Terror]]" (along with, in some markets, "[[Miri (Star Trek: The Original Series)|Miri]]") during the weekend of September 16, 2006,<ref name="remaster_dates">{{cite web|url=http://trekmovie.com/tos-in-hd/hdtv-star-trek-tos-episode-order/|title=TOS Remastered Episode Guide - Season 1|publisher=TrekMovie.com|accessdate=2009-04-28}}</ref> and ended with "The Cage", which aired during the weekend of May 2, 2009.<ref name="cage_remaster">{{cite web|url=http://trekmovie.com/2009/04/22/preview-for-star-trek-remastered-the-cage-airing-next-weekend/|title=First Look: Preview for Star Trek Remastered âThe Cageâ Airing Next Weekend |publisher=TrekMovie.com|date=2009-04-22|accessdate=2009-04-28}}</ref> The remastered air dates listed below are based on the weekend each episode aired in syndication.<ref name="remaster_dates" />

==Episodes== ===Pilots (1964â1965)=== ''Star Trek's'' [[television pilot|pilot episode]], "The Cage", was completed between November 1964 and January 1965,<ref>David Alexander, ''Star Trek Creator: The Authorized Biography of Gene Roddenberry'', p. 218.</ref> and starred [[Jeffrey Hunter]] as [[Christopher Pike (Star Trek)|Captain Christopher Pike]], [[Majel Barrett]] as [[Number One (Star Trek)|Number One]], and [[Leonard Nimoy]] as [[Spock]]. After the pilot was rejected by [[NBC]] as being "too cerebral" (among other complaints),<ref name="cerebral">{{cite book|last = Shatner|first = William| title = Up Till Now: The Autobiography| publisher = [[Thomas Dunne Books]]| location = New York| year = 2008| pages = 119| isbn = 0-312-37265-5 }}</ref> Jeffrey Hunter chose to withdraw from the role of Pike<ref>David Alexander, ''Star Trek Creator: The Authorized Biography of Gene Roddenberry'', p. 244.</ref> when creator [[Gene Roddenberry]] was asked to produce a second pilot episode ("[[Where No Man Has Gone Before]]") of which an edited version of the same name aired in 1966.<ref name="creator">{{cite book|title=Star Trek Creator: The Authorized Biography of Gene Roddenberry|author=Alexander, David|publisher=Roc|year=1994|isbn=0-451-45440-5}}</ref><ref name="making">{{cite book|title=The Making of Star Trek|year=1968|publisher=Ballatine Books|author=Whitfield, Stephen E and Roddenberry, Gene|isbn=1-85286-363-3}}</ref>
"The Cage" never aired during ''Star Trek's'' original run on NBC. It was presented by Roddenberry as a black-and-white [[workprint]] at various [[science fiction convention]]s over the years after ''Star Trek's'' cancellation, but was not released on [[home video]] until 1986, when [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount Home Video]] produced a "restored" release of "The Cage" (a combination of the original black-and-white footage and color portions of the Season 1 episode "[[The Menagerie (Star Trek: The Original Series)|The Menagerie]]") complete with an introduction by Gene Roddenberry.<ref name="cagehistory">{{cite web|url=http://www.trekweb.com/articles/2008/11/12/A-Look-Back-at-The-History-of-Star-Trek-First-Pilot-The-Cage.shtml|title=A Look Back at The History of Star Trek's First Pilot "The Cage"|publisher=TrekWeb.com|date=2008-11-12|accessdate=2009-05-01}}</ref>
On October 4, 1988, Paramount Pictures aired a two-hour television special, hosted by [[Patrick Stewart]], called "The ''Star Trek'' Saga: From One Generation To The Next" which featured, for the first time, a full-color television presentation of "The Cage". In some markets, the special did not air until October 15, 1988.<ref name="cagehistory" /> In the United States, "The Cage" was first released to DVD in December 2001.<ref name="cagedvd">{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/releaseinfo.cfm?ReleaseID=470|title=Volume 40: Turnabout Intruder/The Cage|publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com|accessdate=2009-05-01}}</ref> It was later included on the final disc in both the original and "remastered" Season 3 DVD box sets (listed with the original air date of October 15, 1988).<ref name="s3_dvd" /><ref name="s3_rem" /><ref name="dvd_listing">Both the original Season 3 and "remastered" Season 3 sets list the original air date for "The Cage" as October 15, 1988.</ref>
The also planned-as-pilot "Where No Man Has Gone Before" in its original form (production number 02a) had been forwarded to the NBC, but only a re-worked, re-edited, re-formatted, cut version was later aired under the same name not as a pilot but as the third episode of the series (production number 02b). Afterwards, over the years the original "alternate" version was thought to be lost, but later appeared as bootleg VHS tapes at conventions, until a print of it was discovered in 2009 and subsequently released on home video under the title ''"Where No Fan Has Gone Before" - The Restored, Unaired Alternate Pilot Episode'' as part of the TOS season 3 box set on Blu-ray<ref name="DVD News"/>; it has not been released on DVD, yet. This version remains unaired.

===Season 1 (1966â1967)=== After Roddenberry's second pilot episode, "[[Where No Man Has Gone Before]]", received a more favorable response from [[NBC]],<ref name="creator"/><ref name="making"/> ''Star Trek'' finally aired its first episode - "[[The Man Trap]]" - at 8:30PM on September 8, 1966.<ref name="first_air">{{cite book|title=I Am Spock|author=Leonard Nimoy|year=1995|publisher=Hyperion|pages=38|isbn=0-7868-6182-7|authorlink=Leonard Nimoy}}</ref> "Where No Man...", which eventually aired in a re-edited format as the series' third episode, retained only [[Spock]] as a character from "The Cage", but introduced [[William Shatner]] as [[James T. Kirk|Captain Kirk]], [[James Doohan]] as chief engineer [[Montgomery Scott|Scotty]], and [[George Takei]] as physicist (later, helmsman) [[Hikaru Sulu|Sulu]]. [[DeForest Kelley]] and [[Nichelle Nichols]] joined the cast as ship's surgeon [[Leonard McCoy|Dr. McCoy]] and communications officer [[Uhura]] in "The Man Trap", the first aired episode of the series.
Although her character of Number One was not retained from "The Cage", [[Majel Barrett]] returned to the show as a new character, nurse [[Christine Chapel]], and made her first of many [[recurring character|recurring appearances]] in "[[The Naked Time]]". [[Grace Lee Whitney]] appeared in eight episodes as yeoman [[Janice Rand]], beginning with "The Man Trap". Whitney left the series after "[[The Conscience of the King (Star Trek: The Original Series)|The Conscience of the King]]",<ref name="creator"/><ref>{{cite book|title=Inside Star Trek: The Real Story|author=[[Herbert Franklin Solow|Herbert F. Solow]] and [[Robert H. Justman]]|publisher=Pocket Books|year=1996|isbn=0-671-00974-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Longest Trek: My Tour of the Galaxy|author=[[Grace Lee Whitney]] and Jim Denney|isbn=1884956033|publisher=Quill Driver Books}}</ref> but would later make minor appearances in the [[Star Trek: The Motion Picture|first]], [[Star Trek III: The Search for Spock|third]], [[Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home|fourth]], and [[Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country|sixth]] [[Star Trek (film series)|''Trek'' films]], as well as [[Flashback (Star Trek: Voyager)|one episode]] of the sequel series ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]''.
''Star Trek's'' first season comprises 29 episodes, including the two-part episode "[[The Menagerie (Star Trek: The Original Series)|The Menagerie]]", which includes much of its footage from the original pilot, "The Cage". Other notable episodes include "[[Balance of Terror]]", which introduces the [[Romulan]]s; "[[Space Seed]]", which introduces [[Khan Noonien Singh]] and serves as the basis for ''[[Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan]]''; "[[Errand of Mercy]]", in which the [[Klingon]]s make their first appearance; and the critically acclaimed,<ref>''Entertainment Weekly'' Special Edition Jan. 18, 1995</ref> [[Hugo Award|Hugo-Award-winning]] episode <ref name="hugo">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/?page_id=51|title=1968 Hugo Awards|publisher=TheHugoAwards.org|accessdate=2009-05-01}}</ref> "[[The City on the Edge of Forever]]" which features Kirk, Spock, and McCoy traveling into the past through the [[Guardian of Forever]].

{{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=06 |Title=[[Mudd's Women]] |Aux1=1329.8 |DirectedBy=[[Harvey Hart]] |WrittenBy=[[Gene Roddenberry]] (story)<br>[[Stephen Kandel]] (teleplay) |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1966|10|13}} |AltDate=April 19, 2008 |ProdCode=04 |ShortSummary=The ''Enterprise'' pursues a vessel and rescues its occupants, interstellar con man [[List of Star Trek characters|Harry Mudd]], who is arrested on outstanding charges, and three incredibly beautiful women, his cargo. After Kirk diverts to a mining planet to obtain new lithium crystals for the Enterprise, Mudd negotiates with the three miners there, exchanging his women for lithium crystals for his own profit. Finally, Mudd's deception is revealed as the woman are, in fact, very plain and only appear beautiful due to taking illegal Venus drugs. Kirk obtains the crystals he needs and takes Mudd back into custody.<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }}
{{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=07 |Title=[[What Are Little Girls Made Of?]] |Aux1=2712.4 |DirectedBy=[[James Goldstone]] |WrittenBy=[[Robert Bloch]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1966|10|20}} |AltDate=October 6, 2007 |ProdCode=10 |ShortSummary=In search of [[Christine Chapel|Nurse Chapel's]] fiancÃ©, renowned [[Astrobiology|exobiologist]] Roger Korby, the ''Enterprise'' visits the icy planet Exo III, where Korby has discovered an ancient machine which allows him to duplicate any living person with an [[android (robot)|android]] replacement. {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=08 |Title=[[Miri (Star Trek: The Original Series)|Miri]] |Aux1=2713.5 |DirectedBy=[[Vincent McEveety]] |WrittenBy= [[Adrian Spies]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1966|10|27}} |AltDate= September 16, 2006 |ProdCode=12 |ShortSummary=After discovering what appears to be a duplicate of the planet [[Earth]], Captain Kirk and his [[away team|landing party]] find a population ravaged by a strange disease, which only children appear to have survived.<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }}

{{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=13 |Title=[[The Conscience of the King]] |Aux1=2817.6 |DirectedBy=[[Gerd Oswald]] |WrittenBy=[[Barry Trivers]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1966|12|8}} |AltDate=September 22, 2007 |ProdCode=13 |ShortSummary=While visiting an old friend, Kirk suspects a Shakespearean actor may actually be the murderous former governor of Tarsus IV where Kirk grew up. {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=14 |Title=[[Balance of Terror]] |Aux1=1709.2 |DirectedBy=[[Vincent McEveety]] |WrittenBy=[[Paul Schneider (writer)|Paul Schneider]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1966|12|15}} |AltDate=September 16, 2006 |ProdCode=09 |ShortSummary=While investigating a series of destroyed outposts, the ''Enterprise'' discovers a lone [[Romulan]] vessel with a [[cloaking device]]. {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=15 |Title=[[Shore Leave (Star Trek: The Original Series)|Shore Leave]] |Aux1=3025.3 |DirectedBy=[[Robert Sparr]] |WrittenBy=[[Theodore Sturgeon]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1966|12|29}} |AltDate=May 26, 2007 |ProdCode=17 |ShortSummary=Captain Kirk orders [[shore leave]] for the ''Enterprise'' crew on a seemily uninhabited planet in the Omicron Delta system. Kirk sees (and fights) an image of Finnegan, a rival from his [[Starfleet Academy]] days. Spock discovers that the planet seems to be drawing a large amount of energy from the ship's engines, placing the ''Enterprise'' in danger.<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }}

''(This episode serves as the backstory to the [[Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan|second Star Trek film]]).<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }}

After the ''Enterprise'' is destroyed in an attack simulation, Kirk must fight to keep his crew from death.<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }}

Fontana]] (story and teleplay) |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1967|3|2}} |AltDate=July 28, 2007 |ProdCode=25 |ShortSummary=Despite exposure to deadly radiation, the Federation colony on Omicron Ceti III appears to be thriving. Leila Kalomi, an old friend of Mr. Spock, shows the landing party strange flowers that seem to impose a state of pure bliss on all exposed to its [[spore]]s (even Spock). The spores effects spread rapidly throughout the ''Enterprise'', causing the crew to mutiny against Captain Kirk.<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }}
{{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=25 |Title=[[The Devil in the Dark]] |Aux1=3196.1 |DirectedBy=[[Joseph Pevney]] |WrittenBy=[[Gene L. After wounding the creature, Spock performs a [[Vulcan (Star Trek)#Mind melds|mind meld]], discovering the reason behind the Horta's attacks.<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }}
{{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=26 |Title=[[Errand of Mercy]] |Aux1=3198.4 |DirectedBy=[[John Newland]] |WrittenBy=[[Gene L. Coon]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1967|3|23}} |AltDate=May 12, 2007 |ProdCode=27 |ShortSummary=Peace negotiations have collapsed between the Federation and the warlike [[Klingon|Klingon Empire]]. The ''Enterprise'' is ordered to protect Organia, a peaceful planet located near the Klingon border. Kirk and Spock beam to the surface to warn the Organians about the Klingons, but soon a Klingon fleet arrives, forcing the ''Enterprise'' to abandon the duo on the planet. The natives protect Kirk and Spock, even as [[Kor (Star Trek: The Original Series)|Kor]], the new Klingon governor, orders mass executions of the Organian people. As both Federation and Klingon fleets converge above the planet, Kirk and Spock execute a daring raid on the Klingon headquarters in an effort to destabilize their control over the planet.<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }}
{{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=27 |Title=[[The Alternative Factor]] |Aux1=3087.6 |DirectedBy=[[Gerd Oswald]] |WrittenBy=[[Don Ingalls]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1967|3|30}} |AltDate=December 1, 2007 |ProdCode=20 |ShortSummary=While orbiting an apparently dead planet, the ''Enterprise'' seems to experience a strange moment of "nonexistence." Captain Kirk discovers a man named Lazarus on the planet below, who claims the effect was caused by his "enemy," later revealed to be an insane version of Lazarus from an [[Parallel universe (fiction)|alternate dimension]]. The sane version of Lazarus asks for Kirk's help in defeating his counterpart.<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }}
{{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=28 |Title=[[The City on the Edge of Forever]] |Aux1=3134.0 |DirectedBy=[[Joseph Pevney]] |WrittenBy=[[Harlan Ellison]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1967|4|6}} |AltDate=October 7, 2006 |ProdCode=28 |ShortSummary=After accidentally overdosing on a powerful stimulant, Dr. McCoy acts erratically and disappears through [[Guardian of Forever|the Guardian of Forever]], a newly-discovered [[time portal]] on a remote planet. Kirk and Spock follow after learning that McCoy somehow changed history. Arriving in the 1930s, the duo meet Edith Keeler, a New York social worker who gives them a place to stay. As the days pass, and McCoy is nowhere to be seen, Kirk finds himself falling in love with Keeler... but Spock discovers that Keeler must die to restore the timeline.<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }}
{{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=29 |Title=[[Operation: Annihilate!]] |Aux1=3287.2 |DirectedBy=[[Herschel Daugherty]] |WrittenBy=[[Steven W. Carabatsos]] |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1967|4|13}} |AltDate=February 23, 2008 |ProdCode=29 |ShortSummary=The ''Enterprise'' arrives at Deneva - the home of Captain Kirk's brother, Sam - and discovers that the entire planet has been infested with large, [[Amoeba (genus)|amoeba]]-like aliens that have attacked and killed much of the human population. One of these aliens attaches itself to Spock, who volunteers to become a subject in Dr. McCoy's medical tests. After McCoy accidentally blinds Spock during one of his test procedures, the doctor must quickly find a way to neutralize the dangerous creatures.<ref name="s1_episodes" /> |LineColor=F3CE4E }} |}
===Season 2 (1967â1968)=== The show's 26-episode second season began in September 1967<ref name="airdates" /> with "[[Amok Time]]", which introduced actor [[Walter Koenig]] as [[Russia]]n navigator [[Pavel Chekov]], and granted viewers the first glimpse of [[Spock|Spock's]] homeworld, [[Vulcan (Star Trek)#Homeworld|Vulcan]]. The season also includes such notable episodes as "[[Mirror, Mirror (Star Trek: The Original Series)|Mirror, Mirror]]", which introduces the evil "[[Mirror Universe (Star Trek)|mirror universe]]"; "[[Journey to Babel]]", featuring the introduction of Spock's parents [[Sarek]] and [[List of Star Trek characters (GâM)#G|Amanda]]; and the light-hearted "[[The Trouble With Tribbles]]", which would later be revisited in a 1973 episode of ''[[Star Trek: The Animated Series]]'' and [[Trials and Tribble-ations|a 1996 episode]] of ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]''.

===Season 3 (1968â1969)===
After ''Star Trek's'' second season, NBC was prepared to cancel the show due to low ratings.<ref name="death">{{cite book|title=I Am Spock|author=Leonard Nimoy|year=1995|publisher=Hyperion|pages=112â113|isbn=0-7868-6182-7|authorlink=Leonard Nimoy}}</ref><ref name="death2">{{cite book|last = Shatner|first = William| title = Up Till Now: The Autobiography| publisher = [[Thomas Dunne Books]]| location = New York| year = 2008| pages = 131â132| isbn = 0-312-37265-5 }}</ref> Led by fans [[Bjo Trimble|Bjo and John Trimble]], ''Trek'' viewers inundated NBC with letters protesting the show's demise and pleading the network to renew the series for another year.<ref name="death2" /><ref>David Gerrold, quoting Bjo Trimble, in The World of Star Trek, Ballantine Books, 1973, pp 166</ref> After NBC agreed to produce a third season, the network promised Gene Roddenberry that the show would air in a favorable timeslot (Mondays at 7:30 PM),<ref name="death" /><ref name="death2" /> but later changed the schedule so that ''Trek'' would air in the so-called "[[Friday night death slot|death slot]]" - Friday nights at 10:00PM.<ref name="death"/><ref>William Shatner, Star Trek Memories, Harper Torch, 1994 paperback, p.257</ref> In addition to the "mismanaged"<ref name="death2" /> schedule, the show's budget was "seriously slashed"<ref name="death" /> and Nichelle Nichols described the series' eventual cancellation as "a [[self-fulfilling prophecy]]".<ref>Nichols, Beyond Uhura, p.189</ref>
''Star Trek's'' final, 24-episode season began in September 1968 with "[[Spock's Brain]]".<ref name="airdates" /> The third season also includes "[[The Tholian Web]]", where Kirk becomes trapped between universes; this episode would later be revisited by [[In a Mirror, Darkly|two 2005 episodes]] of the [[prequel]] series ''[[Star Trek: Enterprise]]''. The last episode of the series, "[[Turnabout Intruder]]", aired on June 3, 1969,<ref name="airdates" /> but ''Star Trek'' would eventually return to television in [[cartoon series|animated form]] when ''[[Star Trek: The Animated Series]]'' debuted in September 1973.

Out of the series' 79 episodes, 29 aired on a Thursday, 49 aired on a Friday and "Turnabout Intruder" aired on a Tuesday.
